Nodes are just one of many Bitcoin topics and I approach as many topics as I can. I navigate them, discuss them etc...

Okay, so I need to run/use a node, but therefore need to trust the code. Still requires trust, so I need to hire one or more people to read the code, which requires the knowledge to hire and to trust those. Yeah, this isn't going to happen.

I am talking about the reasons why people don't run/use a node. Your answer is to download Bitcoin core. I am identifying that this excludes a significant number of people. Also, a pruned node, you will lose some people here.
I am using a node, I have told you this before. This conversation started because people said I tell people not to run a node, which isn't true. I am just identifying why people don't.
Just typing quickly, people can't use their node until they set it up and run it. Anyway, why do you think so few people use a node?

Okay, so we agree that some are ignorant and some just want exposure. So there are two reasons. I have never argued against running/using a node. All I have ever pointed out is that there are reasons so few do.

What about the people who know and choose not to run a node, why is this?
What about the people who find Bitcoin really interesting and are stacking but not running/using a node. Why do you think that is?

Why do you think so few people run a node?

There are incentives to, there are incentives that other present to make it easy not to and there are barriers. I am not sure where the strawman is here.
1. The vast majority of the people in the developing world don't have access to a computer. 2. Some do not have a computer with enough disk space. This is the problem with simplistic thinking.
Luckily I am not sending them off a cliff. I am doing a good job of understanding what people don't understand and helping with it. I think hard too.

Remember, my journey is similar but I am a content creator, so here I am identifying that people are also on a journey. Some will go on the same journey as you and some will go on different journeys.

The incentive is there, but: 1. For some, it isn't clear enough 2. Or not important enough for them 3. Or others have provided incentives to not care

That analogy doesn't work in the slightest. Your car comes with a wheel. Your bitcoin doesn't. Happy to work with a fair analogy.

Sorry, not being difficult on purpose, I just want to answer correctly, what is the question you are asking me?
Your problem, like many, is you assume everything thinks like you and should do what you do. People are different.

10/ Very interested in others thoughts here. These are topics I will be exploring over the coming weeks on my podcasts. I am sharpening my tools in understanding some of these topics. Feel free to correct me on any flaws in my arguments.

9/ Theoretical arguments about the optimum free society are great, but how baked in the reality of human nature are they. Even with the big red button, is it just animal nature to sort and arrange in groups with hierarchy, which on scale leads us back to democracy, tyranny etc..

8/ Again, this might just be me, but it is becoming clearer that we should be moving towards living in smaller groups of like-minded people, governed by smaller groups, these groups acting as competition to each other. I guess this is localism, but it still has governance.

7/ Now I also understand that if you engage with the state, in trying to improve it, there is a sound argument for being complicit in its failings. Still, Ron Paul is a Libertarian hero, and he attempted, with much success to challenge traditional political arguments.

6/ The most interesting discussions, for me, are those which look at how we: - Reduce the state - Better governance - Conflict within governance - Increasing freedom - Reducing surveillance - Etc... Achievable goals. Roll on the you statist slave" retorts..."

5/ Democracy may be flawed, but it is the best we have. Plato's alternative to democracy rule by experts", may be sound in theory but is subject to the flaws of humans. Taking away our democratic vote to be replaced by the rule of experts, is one step from authoritarianism."

4/ Similar to the arguments re: democracy being a failed project. The arguments are sound and rationale, but the alternative we have right now is small groups deciding what is best for a country - you know, authoritarians.

3/ The ongoing debate of state v no state has benefit, but it is an argument over something which is unlikely to happen. Sure, Bitcoin can defund the state and move us directionally, but objectively, as a betting man, I think it is less likely than likely.

2/ There is little empathy or patience for the journey that people have to go on here. - Are statists entirely right? No. - Are libertarians entirely right? No. Is there a big red button for switching off the state? No, and even if we had it, it would be dangerous.

20/ 4th Mar - Whistleblower highlights the scale of deaths with body bags in a morgue in Qom. Iranian journalist Mohamad Ahwaze said the number of fatalities was so great there was nowhere to bury the bodies. https:// metro.co.uk/2020/03/04/bod ies-lined-iranian-morgue-lead-accusations-coronavirus-cover-12349854/ …

18/ 2nd March - Sweden becomes the first country to ban flights by Iran Air. A paper by the University of Toronto’s Ashleigh Tuite and others noted that, by February 23, cases of Iranian origin had surfaced in Canada, Lebanon, and the United Arab Emirates.
17/ 28th Feb - Masoumeh Ebtekar, one of the country’s vice presidents, announced that she had the virus.
16/ 25th Feb - 25-year-old Narjes Khanalizadeh, a nurse from the northern city of Lahijan who died, contracting the virus from patients she had been treating in a hospital in the city of Lahijan.

14/ 24th Feb- Ahmad Amirabadi Farahani, MP from Qom, claimed that 50 people had died in his city over a two-week period. Deputy health minister Iraj Harirchi denied Mr Farahani's claim, and said he would resign if the death toll stood at even half that number.

14/ 21st Feb - Iran 2020 elections with the government encouraging people to come out and vote. Low voter turnout is blamed on negative propaganda about Coronavirus. Five days after the election, the number of cases confirmed by the government had risen to 139 with 19 dead.

13/ 19th Feb - Iranian health ministry confirmed the country's first two cases of novel coronavirus. The two patients are reportedly in isolation in the city of Qom. Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei accused Iran's enemies" of exaggerating the threat."

12/ 15th Feb - 6 days before the Iranian elections. Ayatollah Khamenei prevents people from kissing his hand, the reason given is that they wanted to protect the supreme leader. https://www. memri.org/tv/iranian-shi ite-eulogist-nariman-panahi-government-protected-khamenei-coronavirus-early …

Also, NHS workers by contract can be moved to other hospitals. I spoke to a nurse at Bedford hospital. She might be moved to London hospitals at a moments notice, as they are facing a double problem: 1. Accelerating numbers of Covid patients 2. Loss of staff due to sickness

The newly built Nightingale hospital in London is for all Covid recovery patients so that the main hospitals can manage the most emergency cases. Photos of empty hospitals are not signs of a conspiracy, they are hospitals planning for the accelerating growth in Covid patients.

Northwick Park, London’s busiest is now distributing overflow patients to other London hospitals. When London is full, patients will be moved to hospitals outside of London. The hospitals are really a web of services which can either handle overflow or recoveries. Cont...

With regards to empty hospitals, I spoke to my doctor friend. In the UK the NHS has been emptying hospitals of all but emergency treatment. As such, Bedford hospital is half empty. This is strategically to manage the overflow from clusters. Cont...

9/ In times of war soldiers will also say leave no man behind", even at great risk to the other soldiers. Should we not be like that for our fellow man? Also, if everything is voluntary, what do we do about people who may unknowingly become superspreaders?"

8/ Some have suggested that we should accept the collateral damage/short-term pain of pressure on the health system and people dying as the loss of civil liberties and the economy is too big a cost. But should we not try and save as much life as possible?
7/ It would be great to hear responses without shouting statist insults because this does not move anything forward.

6/ While it would be great to live in a perfectly free society, we don't, we live with a state and each state is socialist to some extent. How do we practically navigate this when governments are going to government?

5/ I support some of the central decision making the government has made recently but I am wrestling with enforced lockdown + preservation of life + protect the health system v erosion of civil liberties + collapse of the economy.

4/ My Twitter feed is a Bitcoin, libertarian, ancap bubble. There is another world outside of this where there are different opinions. My only interest here is to understand what people think about this. What is fair? How do we navigate this complicated situation?

3/ If the will of the people is to collectively work together, agree with the government decision to enforce a lockdown and expect a government bailout to fix the economy... should this be respected? If you disagree, what is the alternative?

2/ Additional notes: (a) The only two people who picked B I don't know, they added me as a friend after listening to my show (b) Everyone else picked A How important is the will of the people when we live in a democracy, even if you believe they are wrong?

15/ Looking forward to the latest round of cultists to tell me I’m wrong.
14/ The crypto MoE is a myth and Dash isn’t an SoV either. It is just another coin which is good at marketing. But this marketing is really just propaganda, the likes of which Maduro would be proud.
13/ Now they will claim the Coindesk article is wrong. They will throw some volume stats out there. They will ad hominem. It doesn’t matter. They are lying and exploiting to promote their coin.
12/ Any claims by Dash CEO Ryan Taylor are bullshit. He is a liar and a vulture exploiting Venezuela. People are desperate and it is easy to fake adoption. People want dollars.

11/ “Huge Dash billboards can be seen in the main streets of Caracas, and Dash has even given out cellphones with integrated wallets to boost adoption in the country as part of their well-known marketing scheme.”

10/ But what about the retails accepting it? In a struggling economy it isn’t hard to convince retailers to accept a new currency. Truth is it’s a massive pain and the reports are that it was a waste of time. https://www. google.co.uk/amp/s/www.coin desk.com/despite-ceo-claims-dash-isnt-really-the-most-used-crypto-in-venezuela%3famp=1 …

9/ So what is the reason for someone with a few dollars to: - Buy Dash on an exchange - Find a retailer to accept it - Wait for the payment to confirm There is none, Dash only adds friction with no benefit.

8/ It doesn’t take many brain cells to figure out why Dash has close to no use. Why would you use it as an MoE? The best currency for this is the dollar as it is the most stable. When you are living on a few dollars a month you really need stability.
7/ Quite interestingly, the economy is highly digitised and the majority of people pay using a Venmo style app. Though not everyone has a phone, some share and many don’t have data services.

6/ There are five primary currencies in Venezuela: 1. Bolivar - this is the most used 2. Dollar - this is what people want but is not always available 3. Petro - mother of all shitcoins 4. Colombian Peso - used little 5. Bitcoin - used by a select few

5/ We visited a humanitarian project in one of the slums which feeds single mothers and their children. These people have literally fuck all. Many rely on government handouts, hence why the regime still has some support. Some have the Petro but don’t know how to use it.

4/ For the majority of people, the name of the game is survival. Average monthly salary reports vary from $2-6. Whoever is right, it is really low. Remember this is the average, so there are those on more and those on less. Many work multiple hustles or rely on handouts.

3/ In Caracas the East of the city, on the surface feels like any cosmopolitan city: - Large billboards for Pepsi etc... - Construction - Nice cars (passed a garage selling Porches) The West is propaganda town and more dangerous. There are vast slums which circle the city.

2/ Let’s break down the situation. Firstly Caracas is different from the provinces and in Caracas there is a very clear rich and poor divide. In the provinces they have intermittent power, the people are super poor and can’t access basic supplies.

1/ Let’s talk about Dash in Venezuela and why their stupid shitcoin is exploiting the country with propaganda. The @Dashpay marketing team and bag holders will wax lyrical about how Dash is helping the people of Venezuela. They aren’t.
